items.title: Trump withdraws invitation for Canada to join his global ‘board of peace’
items.standfirst: While leaders of many liberal democracies declined to sign on, Mark Carney had, before Davos, accepted in principleDonald Trump withdrew on Thursday an invitation for Canada to join his “board of peace” initiative aimed at resolving global conflicts.“Please let this Letter serve to represent that the Board of Peace is withdrawing its invitation to you regarding Canada’s joining, what will be, the most prestigious Board of Leaders ever assembled, at any time,” Trump wrote in a Truth Social post directed at the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney. Continue reading...

items.title: TikTok announces it has finalized deal to establish US entity, sidestepping ban
items.standfirst: Majority US-owned venture includes Larry Ellison’s Oracle, private-equity group Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi’s MGXTikTok announced on Thursday it had closed a deal to establish a new US entity, allowing it to sidestep a ban and ending a long legal battle.The deal finalized by ByteDance, TikTok’s Chinese owner, sets up a majority American-owned venture, with investors including Larry Ellison’s Oracle, the private-equity group Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi’s MGX owning 80.1% of the new entity, while ByteDance will own 19.9%. Continue reading...
items.content: Majority US-owned venture includes Larry Ellison’s Oracle, private-equity group Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi’s MGXTikTok announced on Thursday it had closed a deal to establish a new US entity, allowing it to sidestep a ban and ending a long legal battle.The deal finalized by ByteDance, TikTok’s Chinese owner, sets up a majority American-owned venture, with investors including Larry Ellison’s Oracle, the private-equity group Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi’s MGX owning 80.1% of the new entity, while ByteDance will own 19.9%. Continue reading...

items.title: TikTok sets up joint venture to avert threat of US ban
items.standfirst: Popular social media platform TikTok on Thursday set up a mainly American-owned joint venture to operate its US business, in a bid to avert the threat of the app being banned in its biggest market. TikTok’s Chinese owner, ByteDance, has been under pressure to sell after US officials warned that Beijing could use the app to harvest Americans’ data and influence users.
items.content: Popular social media platform TikTok on Thursday set up a mainly American-owned joint venture to operate its US business, in a bid to avert the threat of the app being banned in its biggest market. TikTok’s Chinese owner, ByteDance, has been under pressure to sell after US officials warned that Beijing could use the app to harvest Americans’ data and influence users.

items.title: TikTok Seals Deal to Operate in the US After Years of Drama
items.standfirst: TikTok and its Chinese parent ByteDance Ltd. have closed a long-awaited deal to transfer parts of their US operations to American investors, securing the popular video app’s future in the US and avoiding a nationwide ban.
items.content: TikTok and its Chinese parent ByteDance Ltd. have closed a long-awaited deal to transfer parts of their US operations to American investors, securing the popular video app’s future in the US and avoiding a nationwide ban.

clusters.title: Trump's claim Nato troops avoided Afghanistan front line sparks outrage in UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's claim Nato troops avoided Afghanistan front line sparks outrage in UK

items.title: Trump's claim Nato troops avoided Afghanistan front line sparks outrage in UK
items.standfirst: The US president says Nato troops stayed "a little off the front lines" - despite 457 UK military deaths in the conflict.
items.content: The US president says Nato troops stayed "a little off the front lines" - despite 457 UK military deaths in the conflict.

items.title: ‘Makes my flesh creep’: MPs across political spectrum condemn Trump’s claims about Nato troops – UK politics live
items.standfirst: Labour, Tory and Lib Dem MPs among those criticising US president over claim Nato troops stayed away from frontline in AfghanistanAl Carns, the former Royal Marines officer who is now a defence minister, has posted a video response to Donald Trump’s comments about the record of British and other allied forces in Afghanistan. (See 8.56am.) Without mentioning the president by name, Carns says that his comments are “utterly ridiculous”.Tracking some comments made that Nato troops stayed a little off the front lines in Afghanistan and that the US has never necessarily needed us.Well, it’s a real shame to hear that. The only time Nato’s ever enacted article 5 was after the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States, and the world rallied to the support of the US.Now, some advice for anyone who may be listening. There are two great sayings worth remembering. Number one, there’s only one worse things than working with allies; that is working without them. And when you do, always remember: never above, never below, always side by side. Continue reading...
items.content: Labour, Tory and Lib Dem MPs among those criticising US president over claim Nato troops stayed away from frontline in AfghanistanAl Carns, the former Royal Marines officer who is now a defence minister, has posted a video response to Donald Trump’s comments about the record of British and other allied forces in Afghanistan. (See 8.56am.) Without mentioning the president by name, Carns says that his comments are “utterly ridiculous”.Tracking some comments made that Nato troops stayed a little off the front lines in Afghanistan and that the US has never necessarily needed us.Well, it’s a real shame to hear that. The only time Nato’s ever enacted article 5 was after the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States, and the world rallied to the support of the US.Now, some advice for anyone who may be listening. There are two great sayings worth remembering. Number one, there’s only one worse things than working with allies; that is working without them. And when you do, always remember: never above, never below, always side by side. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump prompts outrage with claim Nato troops avoided frontline in Afghanistan

clusters.title: ICE detains 5-year-old in Minnesota, school official says he was used as ‘bait’
clusters.neutral_headline: US officers detain 5-year-old boy as Minnesota immigration raids continue

items.title: ICE detains 5-year-old in Minnesota, school official says he was used as ‘bait’
items.standfirst: US Immigration and Enforcement (ICE) officers this week detained five-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos in Minnesota as he was returning home from preschool, with school officials and witnesses saying agents used the child to lure out and arrest his father. The witnesses also said that the agents refused to leave him in the care of another adult, "essentially using him as bait”.
items.content: US Immigration and Enforcement (ICE) officers this week detained five-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos in Minnesota as he was returning home from preschool, with school officials and witnesses saying agents used the child to lure out and arrest his father. The witnesses also said that the agents refused to leave him in the care of another adult, "essentially using him as bait”.

items.title: US officers detain 5-year-old boy as Minnesota immigration raids continue

items.content: The boy was taken along with his father, the lawyer and school officials say. ICE says it kept the boy safe as his father ran.

items.title: Lecornu survives first of two no-confidence motions
items.standfirst: France's National Assembly voted down on Friday the first of two no-confidence motions against the government of Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu over the forced passage of the 2026 budget bill.The mo...
items.content: France's National Assembly voted down on Friday the first of two no-confidence motions against the government of Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu over the forced passage of the 2026 budget bill.The mo...

items.title: French Prime Minister benefits from support due to international turmoil
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu faces two votes of no-confidence, which he is likely to survive. This means he will be pushing the 2026 budget through thanks to the controversial 49.3 legal instrument. He benefits from support from the socialist party and the republican party, who consider stability is necessary regarding current international turmoil. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle breaks it down for us.
items.content: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu faces two votes of no-confidence, which he is likely to survive. This means he will be pushing the 2026 budget through thanks to the controversial 49.3 legal instrument. He benefits from support from the socialist party and the republican party, who consider stability is necessary regarding current international turmoil. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle breaks it down for us.

items.title: French PM Lecornu survives second no-confidence vote over budget
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu on Friday survived two no-confidence votes, triggered by the country's far-left and far-right parties after the premier resorted to forcing through a budget without a parliamentary vote.
items.content: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu on Friday survived two no-confidence votes, triggered by the country's far-left and far-right parties after the premier resorted to forcing through a budget without a parliamentary vote.

items.title: French Prime Minister faces dual no-confidence votes over budget
items.standfirst: On January 20, French Prime Minister used the controversial 49.3 legal instrument that allowed him to push the 2026 budget through Parliament, triggering two votes of no-confidence from the far-left and the far-right. Those challenges are unlikely to be successful, but the debate is still going to take place. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot told us about the political implications of these votes live from the National Assembly in Paris.
items.content: On January 20, French Prime Minister used the controversial 49.3 legal instrument that allowed him to push the 2026 budget through Parliament, triggering two votes of no-confidence from the far-left and the far-right. Those challenges are unlikely to be successful, but the debate is still going to take place. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot told us about the political implications of these votes live from the National Assembly in Paris.

items.title: Live: Russia insists Ukraine must pull out of Donbass for any deal to end the war
items.standfirst: Russia on Friday insisted that Kyiv must withdraw from the Donbass region in eastern Ukraine for any deal to end the nearly four-year war. The demand comes just hours before negotiators representing Ukraine, Russia and the United States are set to meet in Abu Dhabi for a first trilateral meeting. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.standfirst: Us President Donald Trump has backed away from his threats of tariffs on European countries to push them to agree to a US purchase of Greenland. he also launched the plan for his Board of Peace, although a long list of countries has rejected the invitation to join as it appears to want to rival the United Nations. The EU stays on its guard.

items.title: State-wide anti-ICE protest gears up in Minnesota as 5 year-old boy arrested
items.standfirst: The US state of Minnesota is bracing for a statewide day of protest. Residents are expected to stay home on January 23, shutting down schools and businesses to "ICE out ICE", protesting the intensified immigration crackdown sweeping the state. Vice President JD Vance visited Minneapolis on January 22, backing the enforcement and warning local officials to cooperate.

clusters.title: Spain train crash death toll rises to 45 after two more bodies found
clusters.neutral_headline: Spain train crash death toll rises to 45 after two more bodies found

items.title: Spain train crash death toll rises to 45 after two more bodies found
items.standfirst: Spanish investigators on Thursday recovered two more bodies from the wreckage of a high-speed train collision last weekend, raising the death toll to 45. Deadly back-to-back rail accidents just days apart have fuelled safety concerns in Spain, which observed three days of mourning after the crash in Andalusia, its deadliest rail disaster in over a decade.
items.content: Spanish investigators on Thursday recovered two more bodies from the wreckage of a high-speed train collision last weekend, raising the death toll to 45. Deadly back-to-back rail accidents just days apart have fuelled safety concerns in Spain, which observed three days of mourning after the crash in Andalusia, its deadliest rail disaster in over a decade.

items.title: Spanish train drivers call three-day strike after deadly railway crashes
items.standfirst: Union is demanding better safety standards for workers and passengers after two collisions this week killed 46Spain’s largest train drivers’ union has called a three-day nationwide strike to demand measures to guarantee the safety of railworkers and passengers after two deadly crashes this week killed at least 46 people, including two drivers.The death toll from Sunday’s collision between two trains near the Andalucían town of Adamuz rose from 43 to 45 on Thursday afternoon after two more bodies were recovered from the crash site. On Tuesday, a driver was killed and 37 people injured when a train was derailed by the collapse of a retaining wall near Gelida in Catalonia. Continue reading...

On Tuesday, a driver was killed and 37 people injured when a train was derailed by the collapse of a retaining wall near Gelida in Catalonia. Continue reading...

clusters.title: A Wikipedia Group Made a Guide to Detect AI Writing. Now a Plug-In Uses It to ‘Humanize’ Chatbots
clusters.neutral_headline: A Wikipedia Group Made a Guide to Detect AI Writing. Now a...

items.title: A Wikipedia Group Made a Guide to Detect AI Writing. Now a Plug-In Uses It to ‘Humanize’ Chatbots
items.standfirst: The web’s best resource for spotting AI writing has ironically become a manual for AI models to hide it.
items.content: The web’s best resource for spotting AI writing has ironically become a manual for AI models to hide it.

items.title: Wikipedia volunteers spent years cataloging AI tells. Now there's a plugin to avoid them.
items.standfirst: The web's best guide to spotting AI writing has become a manual for hiding it.
items.content: On Saturday, tech entrepreneur Siqi Chen released an open source plugin for Anthropic's Claude Code AI assistant that instructs the AI model to stop writing like an AI model. Called "Humanizer," the simple prompt plugin feeds Claude a list of 24 language and formatting patterns that Wikipedia editors have listed as chatbot giveaways. Chen published the plugin on GitHub, where it has picked up over 1,600 stars as of Monday. "It's really handy that Wikipedia went and collated a detailed list of 'signs of AI writing,'" Chen wrote on X. "So much so that you can just tell your LLM to... not do that." The source material is a guide from WikiProject AI Cleanup, a group of Wikipedia editors who have been hunting AI-generated articles since late 2023. French Wikipedia editor Ilyas Lebleu founded the project. The volunteers have tagged over 500 articles for review and, in August 2025, published a formal list of the patterns they kept seeing.Read full article Comments
